description.narrative:
About READ-It - Over the past 20 years there has been a concerted effort to use reliable evidence in making decisions about health care. READ-It aims to improve the evidence base and ensure its dissemination. READ-It helps ensure healthcare problems relevant to low- and middle-income countries are addressed, and that people living in these countries are part of the process. It is a major contributor to Cochrane, a global organization committed to preparing and updating systematic reviews, and coordinates the Cochrane Infectious Diseases Group (CIDG) and assists Cochrane in developing methods and editorial processes. It also works closely with policy makers.
READ-It focuses on two main areas: - Reliable, up-to-date, scientifically defensible and relevant evidence in malaria and tuberculosis, child health, maternal health and health systems. - Effective dialogue and influence between research, policy and practice communities in public and private sector.
READ-It's activities include: - Preparing and updating Cochrane Reviews about the effects of health care relevant to low- and middle-income countries. - Identifying approaches to ensure dissemination and use of the results of systematic reviews in decision making.

participating-org.narrative: Centre for Evidence-based Health Care at the University of Stellenbosch (South Africa)
Cochrane Effective Practice and Organization of Care Group, at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (Norway)
Cochrane South Africa at the South African Medical Research Council (South Africa)
International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (The Union)
UK - Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office
University of Zambia, School of Public Health

activity-date.narrative: Current work plan and funding is planned to finish on 31 March 2024.

READ-It is currently in Implementation Year 3 of the programme and continues to work on the “core” READ-It projects as detailed below and the continued contribution to the COVID-19 pandemic.
During Implementation Years 1-2, READ-It have worked on the “core” READ-It projects and the completion of high impact (and high priority) Cochrane reviews, other systematic reviews, and peer research papers in the “core” topic areas.
READ-It’s “core” topics are in neglected tropical diseases, vector control, malaria and tuberculosis, nutrition in public health and health systems development, mental health in primary care, qualitative evidences synthesis in NTDs and tuberculosis; and from the beginning of Implementation Year 2 also rapidly pivoted to include COVID-19.
READ-It’s response mode to the COVID-19 pandemic included collaborative efforts with the Central Cochrane Editorial Production Team and the Birmingham-led COVID-19 diagnostic review group, with outputs being published in the CIDG portfolio; South Africa and India READ-It supported partners leading COVID-19 Guidance development.
READ-It continue to contribute to various global and national published guidelines on priority topics including specific COVID-19 guidelines in Year 2 which is continuing into Year 3. READ-It are also contributing to leadership with a programme of work designed to influence national decision-making process with the start of Eleanor Ochodo’s MRC/DFID African Research Leader scheme.
In Year 2, CIDG a partner within READ-It at LSTM gained new official WHO Collaborating Centre status to carry out systematic reviews in malaria and tuberculosis to assist with guideline production for WHO (February 2020 to March 2024); and a Qualitative Evidence Synthesis Hub was established between South Africa and UK, conducting a suite of QES reviews and methodological development.
During the Inception phase from 15 May 2018 to 31 March 2019, READ-It covered various activities which included conducting consultations, literature scanning and consensus building to identify review topics that are important questions to our stakeholders and potentially high impact; built consensus with partners on new protocols for years one and two; developed outlines for methods projects to advance the science of synthesis; conducted a planning and consultation meeting with all potential partners and DFID (now FCDO). READ-It set up work plans and contracts with all new partners; liaised with the World Health Organization and PAHO, taking on several topics in our response mode; and drafted a code of conduct and safeguarding procedures.

recipient-country.narrative:
The BNMT team’s main interests are systematic reviews tailored to national policy questions, incorporating national situational analysis, so that the review findings are directly relevant to national decision making.
The BNMT team’s main area of work within READ-It involves conducting high priority reviews to inform government to reform and develop policies related to Vitamin A supplementation; calcium supplementation and suicide prevention in LMIC’s.

The Campbell Collaboration (New Delhi office) team’s main interests are related supporting evidence-informed decisions to the poor, including women, in India and elsewhere by the creation of an evidence synthesis hub in India; support to production of evidence synthesis products; and advocating for and discussing evidence-informed decisions by national decision makers through events.
The Campbell Collaboration (New Delhi office) team’s main area of work within READ-It involves conducting priority reviews (and gap maps) on the effectiveness of prevention and intervention programs for child neglect in LMIC’s, and access to electricity for improving health, education and welfare in LMICs.

The EPPI-Centre is committed to informing policy and professional practice with sound evidence. As such, it is involved in two main areas of work: systematic reviews - this includes developing methods for systematic reviews and research syntheses, conducting reviews, supporting others to undertake reviews, and providing guidance and training in this area; and research use - this includes studying the use/non-use of research evidence in personal, practice and political decision-making, supporting those who wish to find and use research to help solve problems, and providing guidance and training in this area.
The EPPI-Centre team’s main area of work within READ-It involves contributing to substantive and methodological outputs in collaboration with other global READ-It Partners about: mass drug administration; adherence to HIV/AIDS antiretroviral therapy; access to electricity review; saturation in qualitative synthesis; and other outputs conducted with READ-It partners. Also involved in collating methodological learning accrued from and for individual READ-It reviews, and across the READ-It portfolio; and indicate where they have been applied in READ-It reviews.

The Union South East Asia team’s main interests are related to the National TB Elimination Program (NTEP) which is working towards TB elimination by 2025 in a mission mode. Most of the TB patients in India belong to marginal and vulnerable communities. The proposed evidence synthesis aims at aiding the NTEP take evidence-based decisions on key program performance like treatment adherence and engaging private sector which would propel the NTEP goals of TB elimination and benefit thousands of vulnerable TB patients including women and children.
The Union South East Asia team’s main area of work within READ-It involves conducting high priority reviews on TB topics.

The Zambia team contributes to improving health outcome through the application of reliable evidence synthesis, increasing number of evidence-informed decisions hopefully globally, regionally, and/or nationally to benefit the poor in LMIC’s including women.
The Zambia team’s main area of work within READ-It involves interventions to keep adolescent girls in School, and interventions to prevent road traffic accidents in Africa.

The main African Network lead is based at the Stellenbosch University, and they work jointly with Cochrane South Africa who are based at the South African Medical Research Council. The official SA partnership is the Centre for Evidence-based Health Care (CEBHC).
CEBHA’s main areas of work involves conducting and supporting relevant high impact/priority Cochrane and non-Cochrane systematic reviews in LMICs; engaging with decision makers and influencing policies in priority areas for the region; focused review dissemination strategies; training/capacity development of stakeholder groups to use systematic reviews; and contributions to national guideline development.

The main lead of READ-It is based at the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine (LSTM) which co-ordinates with the planning, management, monitoring the strategy, work plans, outputs and expenditure of READ-It; management of the budgeting and financial disbursements of READ-It funds; assuring value for money and risk management across all global Partners; and the communication with all global Partners.
Also, one of the READ-It Partners, the Cochrane Infectious Diseases Group (CIDG) is based at LSTM.
CIDG’s main areas of work are on determination of the effects of interventions on the prevention or treatment of infectious diseases of relevance to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, particularly malaria, TB, HIV/AIDS, neglected tropical diseases, and diarrhoeal diseases in LMIC's. Also, from March 2020 CIDG have worked on urgent and relevant reviews related to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The aims of the CIDG are to impact on policy and research in tropical diseases through the production of relevant high impact and high priority systematic reviews and to lead developments in review quality improvement and effective dissemination of findings.
The READ-It Liverpool office also managed a Gold Open Access dashboard (with value for money) which is used to cover Gold Open Access costs (as required by FCDO) for all READ-It partners (Liverpool and global).
Also covered some potential global partners costs before official subcontracts are in place (Inception phase).

sector.narrative: READ-It's overall outcome is to increase the number of evidence-informed decisions by global, regional and national decision makers that benefit the poor and vulnerable, including women
